plan:
If I bid higher than my value, I win when my bid is the highest but I lose when the second-highest bid is higher than my value, leading to a loss in profit. I'd regret my bid in this scenario as it's risky.

If I bid equal to my value, I win when my value is the highest. However, I lose when the second-highest bid is equal to or higher than my value, eliminating any profit. I might regret this bid if I constantly lose despite winning the prize.

If I bid lower than my value, I win when my bid is the highest and profit from the value-bid difference. But if the second highest bid is higher than mine, I lose. I'd rarely regret this strategy, as it's least risky and typically profitable.

My final bid is 45 Euro.

If my bid is higher than my value, I would win when my bid is the highest but I will lose the total amount of my bid which can be a loss in the long run. I might regret taking too much risk. 

If the bid equals my value, I win when my bid is highest but lose nothing when I don't win. This strategy is safe with zero regret.

If I bid lower, I win when my bid is the highest, and if I don't win, I lose nothing with potential regrets of not bidding higher.

If my bid is higher than my value, I win when the bids from Andy and Betty are lower than my bid. However, I lose when their bids exceed my value as I would have to pay more than it's worth. Hence, I might regret it as this does not maximize my profit.

When my bid is equal to my value, I win if my opponents' bids are lower, but lose to higher bids. I won't regret my bid since the outcome is fair depending on the competition.

If my bid is lower than my value, I win when Andy and Betty bid below mine. I lose when any bid tops mine - no regrets because I’m only willing to pay up to my bid while protecting my profit.

For the final bid, I’ll consider bidding the average of my value and the previous winning bid. This balances risk between overbidding and losing out on the value.

I plan to adjust my bidding strategy according to the provided round history. I will slightly increase my bid, closer to my value but not exceeding it, to ensure a balance between risk and reward. I'll consider a bid of 50 Euro.

My next strategy involves varying my bids. If I draw a high value, I'll bid slightly lower to leverage the pay second-highest bid rule, maximizing profits. If my value is mid-range, I'll bid close to it. For low values, I'll bid defensively, minimizing potential loss.

My plan involves adopting an agile approach and testing moderate risk strategies. If my loss margin from previous rounds is low, I'll bid slightly above my assigned value. Conversely, if the loss margin is high, I'll bid near my value to minimize risk while maximizing the chance of winning.

I'll strategize to place my bid around my value, slightly less or more depending on the trend in opposition's bidding. If they're consistently on higher side, I can take a risk of bidding above my value. I'll learn and refine the approach each round.

In the next rounds, I'll take a mixed strategy. For high values (60-99), I'll bid slightly lower (about 90% of the value). For mid-range values (30-59), I'll bid around 75% of the value. For low values (0-29), I'll bid defensively, 50% of the value, minimizing loss.

Given the results, I plan to bid between my value and the previous top bid to minimize risk and balance potential profit. I also aim to analyze and predict the competition's bidding range for adjustment of my strategy.

In the upcoming rounds, I plan to experiment by placing my bid slightly lower than my value to observe the trend in profits. I will study if this risk-averse strategy proves beneficial, making sure to adjust my bid based on the competitors' previous approaches.

Next, I will bid exactly 80% of my drawn value for high and medium ranges (above 30) to maximize safe profit. For low values (less than 30), I will bid conservatively at 50% to minimize any potential loss.

My plan moving forward includes implementing an adaptive bidding strategy, which involves observing trends in opponents' bids and adjusting mine accordingly, favoring slightly underbidding my value to increase net profit. Additionally, considering occasional aggressive bids for data collection.
